turns.content: Hello! I'm Sofia Andersson. I'm a medical student and I have some questions about managing a heavy study schedule.
Hi Sofia! Medical school is definitely demanding. I'd love to help — what year are you in, and what are you finding most challenging right now?
I'm in my fourth year at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm. The clinical rotations have been intense, especially since I'm focusing on pediatric neurology.

Karolinska is one of the top medical schools in the world, so the rigor makes sense. Pediatric neurology is a fascinating but demanding specialty. What's making the rotations particularly tough for you?

It's mostly the emotional side. Working with children who have neurological conditions takes a toll. My mom actually understands this well — she's a nurse, Anna Andersson. She keeps telling me it gets easier with time.

Having a parent in healthcare must be both a blessing and a source of real understanding. She's right that you build emotional resilience over time, but it's important not to just push through — processing those feelings matters. Do you have a support system beyond your mom?
I do. My brother Erik is great to talk to. He's a lawyer, so he's in a completely different world, but he's a really good listener. We try to have dinner together every Sunday.

That weekly dinner with Erik sounds like a valuable ritual. Sometimes having someone outside of medicine to talk to gives you the best perspective. How are you handling the actual study workload alongside rotations?

That's the hard part. I have board exams coming up in four months, and I need to review neuroscience, pharmacology, and pediatrics all at once. I've been using spaced repetition with Anki, but I feel like I'm falling behind.

Anki is excellent for long-term retention, so you're on the right track there. Four months is actually a reasonable window if you structure it well. Are you spacing your review sessions across all three subjects, or are you doing one at a time?
I've been trying to interleave them, but I end up spending most of my time on neuroscience because it's the most complex. Pharmacology and pediatrics keep getting pushed to the weekend.

That's a common trap — we tend to gravitate toward the subject that feels most urgent. One approach is to time-box each subject: give neuroscience your peak focus hours, but protect at least 30 minutes daily for each of the other two. That way nothing goes stale.
That's really practical advice. I also want to start doing some research in pediatric epilepsy. My supervisor Dr. Lindqvist has a project she wants me to join, but I'm worried about overcommitting.

Research experience is important for your specialty, but timing matters. Could you have an honest conversation with Dr. Lindqvist about starting with a limited role — maybe just the literature review portion — until your boards are done?
She's actually very understanding. I think she'd be open to that. I could probably manage five hours a week on the literature review without it affecting my study schedule too much.

Five hours a week sounds sustainable, and a literature review is the perfect low-pressure entry point. It'll also reinforce your neuroscience studying since there's likely significant overlap with pediatric epilepsy. Just be honest with yourself if it starts cutting into your board prep.
